[[File:Wedding of Prince Albert, Duke of York and Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon.jpg|thumb|right|230px|Wedding photo with the Duke of York wearing RAF full dress in the rank of group captain]]
The '''wedding of Prince Albert, Duke of York''' (later [[George VI of the United Kingdom|King George VI]]), '''and [[Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon|Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon]]''' took place on 26 April 1923 at [[Westminster Abbey]].
==Courtship and proposals== Prince Albert, Duke of York â "Bertie" to the family â was the second son of [[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]]. He initially proposed to Elizabeth in 1921, but she turned him down, being "afraid never, never again to be free to think, speak and act as I feel I really ought to".<ref>{{citation|last=Ezard|first=John|title=A life of legend, duty and devotion |newspaper=The Guardian|date=1 April 2002|page=18}}</ref> When he declared he would marry no one else, his mother, [[Mary of Teck|Queen Mary]], visited [[Glamis Castle|Glamis]] to see for herself the girl who had stolen her son's heart. She became convinced that Elizabeth was "the one girl who could make Bertie happy", but nevertheless refused to interfere.<ref>{{citation |last=Airlie |first=Mabell |authorlink=Mabell Ogilvy, Countess of Airlie |title=Thatched with Gold |publisher=Hutchinson |location=London |year=1962 |page=167}}</ref> At the same time, Elizabeth was courted by [[James Stuart, 1st Viscount Stuart of Findhorn|James Stuart]], Albert's [[equerry]], until he left the prince's service for a better-paid job in the American oil business.<ref>Shawcross, pp. 133â135</ref>
In February 1922, Elizabeth was a bridesmaid at the wedding of Albert's sister, [[Mary, Princess Royal and Countess of Harewood|Princess Mary]], to [[Henry Lascelles, 6th Earl of Harewood|Viscount Lascelles]].<ref>Shawcross, pp. 135â136</ref> The following month, Albert proposed again, but she refused him once more.<ref>Shawcross, p. 136</ref> Eventually, in January 1923, Elizabeth agreed to marry Albert, despite her misgivings about royal life.<ref>{{citation |last=Longford |first=Elizabeth |authorlink=Elizabeth Pakenham, Countess of Longford |title=The Queen Mother |publisher=Weidenfeld & Nicolson |year=1981 |page=23}}</ref> Albert's freedom in choosing Elizabeth, legally a [[Commoners in the United Kingdom|commoner]] though the daughter of a peer, was considered a gesture in favour of political modernisation; previously, princes were expected to marry princesses from other royal families.<ref>Roberts, pp. 57â58; Shawcross, p. 113</ref>
==Wedding== Prince Albert, Duke of York, and Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon were married on 26 April 1923 in [[Westminster Abbey]]. Unexpectedly,<ref>Shawcross, p. 177</ref> Elizabeth laid her bouquet at the Tomb of [[the Unknown Warrior]] on her way into the Abbey.<ref>{{citation |last=Vickers |first=Hugo |title=Elizabeth: The Queen Mother |publisher=Arrow Books/Random House |year=2006 |isbn=9780099476627 |page=64}}</ref>
Lady Elizabeth was attended by eight bridesmaids: *[[Mary Somerset, Duchess of Beaufort|The Lady Mary Cambridge]] (26), daughter of [[Adolphus Cambridge, 1st Marquess of Cambridge|the Marquess]] and Marchioness of Cambridge, great-niece of Queen Mary and thus a cousin of the groom *[[Lady May Abel Smith|The Lady May Cambridge]] (17), daughter of [[Princess Alice, Countess of Athlone|Princess Alice]] and [[Alexander Cambridge, 1st Earl of Athlone|the Earl of Athlone]], niece of Queen Mary and thus first cousin of the groom *The Lady Mary Thynn (20), daughter of [[Thomas Thynne, 5th Marquess of Bath|the Marquess]] and Marchioness of Bath *The Lady Katharine Hamilton (23), daughter of [[James Hamilton, 3rd Duke of Abercorn|the Duke]] and [[Rosalind Hamilton, Duchess of Abercorn|Duchess of Abercorn]] *The Hon Diamond Hardinge (22), daughter of [[Charles Hardinge, 1st Baron Hardinge of Penshurst|Lord]] and Lady Hardinge *The Hon Cecilia Bowes-Lyon (11), daughter of [[Patrick Bowes-Lyon, 15th Earl of Strathmore and Kinghorne|Lord]] and Lady Glamis, niece of the bride *The Hon Mary Elizabeth Elphinstone (11), daughter of [[Sidney Buller-Fullerton-Elphinstone, 16th Lord Elphinstone|Lord]] and [[Mary Elphinstone, Lady Elphinstone|Lady Elphinstone]], niece of the bride *Miss Betty Cator (later sister-in-law to the bride, as Hon Mrs Michael Bowes-Lyon)
==Bride's dress== Elizabeth's wedding dress featured embroidered with pearls and a silver thread, which was made from deep ivory chiffon moire.<ref name="BousfieldToffoli2002">{{cite book|last1=Bousfield|first1=Arthur|last2=Toffoli|first2=Garry|title=Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, 1900-2002: The Queen Mother and Her Century|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=t6PQ84ovPcMC&pg=PA40|accessdate=30 April 2011|date=26 September 2002|publisher=Dundurn Press Ltd.|isbn=9781550023916|page=40}}</ref> It was intended to match the traditional [[Flanders lace]] provided for the train by Queen Mary.<ref name="BousfieldToffoli2002"/> Elizabeth's dress, which was in the fashion of the early 1920s, was designed by Madame Handley Seymour, who had been a dressmaker to Queen Mary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fashion-era.com/queen_mother.htm|title= The Duchess of York's Wedding Dress|publisher=Fashion Era|accessdate=20 April 2011}}</ref>
A strip of Brussels lace, inserted in the dress, was a Strathmore family heirloom. A female ancestor of the bride wore it a grand ball for "Bonnie Prince Charlie", [[Charles Edward Stuart]].<ref name=ladybetty>{{cite news|last=Bronner|first=Milton|title=Medieval gown for Lady Betty|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HPRXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FkUNAAAAIBAJ&dq=wedding%20dress&pg=2165%2C4832492|accessdate=30 April 2011|newspaper=The Toledo News-Bee|date=24 April 1923}}</ref>
The silver leaf girdle had a trail of spring green tulle, trailing to the ground; silver and rose thistle fastened it. According to an era news article: "In the trimming the bride has defied all old superstitions about the unluckiness of green."<ref name=ladybetty />
Unlike more recent dresses, details of this one were publicly revealed in advance of the wedding day.<ref name=ladybetty /> However, the dress was worked on until the last possible opportunity: the day before the wedding, Elizabeth divided her time between the wedding rehearsal and her dressmakers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dull grey skies and raw winds for Royal wedding|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5d9PAAAAIBAJ&sjid=w1QDAAAAIBAJ&dq=wedding%20dress&pg=5283%2C4928500|accessdate=30 April 2011|newspaper=The Evening Independent|date=25 April 1923|agency=Associated Press|location=St. Petersburg FL}}</ref>
Prince Albert wore [[Royal Air Force uniform#Full dress|RAF full dress]] in the rank of [[group captain]], his senior service rank at the time of his marriage.
The newly formed [[British Broadcasting Company]] had wanted to record and broadcast the event on radio, but the [[Chapter (religion)|Chapter]] vetoed the idea (although the [[List of Deans of Westminster|Dean]], [[Herbert Edward Ryle]], was in favour).<ref>{{citation |last=Reith |first=John |authorlink=John Reith |title=Into the Wind |publisher=Hodder and Staughton |location=London |year=1949 |page=94}}</ref> Albert's marriage to a British commoner was considered a modernising gesture.<ref>Roberts, pp. 57-58.</ref>
Upon their marriage, Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon was styled ''[[Royal Highness|Her Royal Highness]] [[Duchess of York|The Duchess of York]]''.<ref>Shawcross, p. 168</ref> Following a wedding breakfast at [[Buckingham Palace]] prepared by chef [[Gabriel Tschumi]], they honeymooned at [[Polesden Lacey]], a manor house in [[Surrey]], and then went to Scotland, where she caught "unromantic" [[whooping cough]].<ref>Letter from Albert to Queen Mary, 25 May 1923, quoted in Shawcross, p. 185</ref>
